prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: We have computed the integration times needed to detect CO (2-1) based on the well-measured IR bolometric luminosities of our targets. We use the LIR-L'CO relation of Daddi et al (2010) and Genzel et al (2010) valid for normal, MS galaxies. We then reduce the predicted CO luminosities by a factor of 3 based on the observations of local ULIRGs, whose star formation efficiency (SFE=LIR/L'CO) is 3 times smaller than that of local spirals. In Table 1, we give the sensitivity requirements and integration times for each individual target to reach a significance of 5σ. We then group the targets into three categories (science goal I-bright and 2-faint and 3-faint) based on a requirement to achieve a given sensitivity (either 0.2 or 0.1 mJy) that reduces the overall overheads. Given that our single aim is to detect the level of CO emission in off-MS galaxies, we request a compact configuration of ALMA, yielding a resolution of 3 arcsec; this ensures that we can recover the total flux from each source without the risk of resolving out some of the power. The bandwidth for the required sensitivity is chosen to be 400 km/s that likely matches the typical line width (FWHM) of our sample. CO is expected to be detected at the following observed frequencies (PACS 357: 92.77 GHz; PACS 682: 93.37 GHz; PACS 825: 91.52 GHz) due to the redshifts given in science justifications. The total observing time for Sg 1 in band-3 is 1.42 hours including overheads.

We have computed the integration times needed to detect CO (2-1) based on the well-measured IR bolometric luminosities of our targets. We use the LIR-L'CO relation of Daddi et al (2010) and Genzel et al (2010) valid for normal, MS galaxies. We then reduce the predicted CO luminosities by a factor of 3 based on the observations of local ULIRGs, whose star formation efficiency (SFE=LIR/L'CO) is 3 times smaller than that of local spirals. In Table 1, we give the sensitivity requirements and integration times for each individual target to reach a significance of 5σ. We then group the targets into three categories (science goal I-bright and 2-faint and 3-faint (cycle 1 targets bot observed yet)) based on a requirement to achieve a given sensitivity (either 0.2 or 0.1 mJy) that reduces the overall overheads. Given that our single aim is to detect the level of CO emission in off-MS galaxies, we request a compact configuration of ALMA, yielding a resolution of 3 arcsec; this ensures that we can recover the total flux from each source without the risk of resolving out some of the power. CO is expected to be detected at the following frequencies based on the redshifts of our sources (PACS-829: 92.74 GHz, 803631: 91.5 GHz). The bandwidth for the required sensitivity is chosen to be 400 km/s that likely matches the typical line width (FWHM) of our sample. The total observing time for SG-2 in band-3 is 3.9 hours including overheads.

We have computed the integration times needed to detect CO (2-1) based on the well-measured IR bolometric luminosities of our targets. We use the LIR-L'CO relation of Daddi et al (2010) and Genzel et al (2010) valid for normal, MS galaxies. We then reduce the predicted CO luminosities by a factor of 3 based on the observations of local ULIRGs, whose star formation efficiency (SFE=LIR/L'CO) is 3 times smaller than that of local spirals. In Table 1, we give the sensitivity requirements and integration times for each individual target to reach a significance of 5σ. We then group the targets into three categories (science goal I-bright, 2-faint and 3-faint (cycle 1 targets as well-not observed)) based on a requirement to achieve a given sensitivity (either 0.2 or 0.1 mJy) that reduces the overall overheads. CO is expected to be detected at the following frequencies based on the redshifts of our targets (PACS-325:86.8 GHz, PACS-299: 87.1 GHz, PACS-867: 89.8 GHz). Given that our single aim is to detect the level of CO emission in off-MS galaxies, we request a compact configuration of ALMA, yielding a resolution of 3 arcsec; this ensures that we can recover the total flux from each source without the risk of resolving out some of the power. The bandwidth for the required sensitivity is chosen to be 400 km/s that likely matches the typical line width (FWHM) of our sample. The total observing time with ALMA in band-3 is 11.2 hours including overheads.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: It is unclear as to whether the most rapidly star-forming galaxies operate in a mode of star formation dissimilar from the majority that populate the so-called Main Sequence (MS). Two scenarios are commonly considered: (1) the sudden accumulation of gas at the bottom of the potential well, triggered by a major merger (or by a disk instability), is boosting a highly efficient conversion of gas into stars, or (2) MS outliers may form stars in the same mode (i.e. efficiency) as MS galaxies, but just happen to be exceptionally gas rich. We can directly test this by determining whether the star formation efficiency is different from that of MS galaxies. A NIR spectroscopic survey of star-forming galaxies in COSMOS with z~1.6 using Subaru/FMOS is enabling us to identify galaxies detected by Hershel/PACS and having extreme offsets from the MS. We propose to obtain CO measurements for a final sample of 10 such galaxies with accurate spectroscopic redshifts and SFRs based on Hα and FIR luminosity. ALMA observations will nicely complement published CO studies of MS galaxies and lay the groundwork for future (sub)mm studies of such extreme events including those at higher spatial resolution.
prp:ObsProposal.prp:previousProposals: Project code: 2012.1.00952.S Title: Molecular gas content of EXTREME outliers from the star-forming main sequence at z~1.5 PI. John Silverman
